newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore jet fuel soars on short covering.
newsitem.headline: Singapore jet fuel soars on short covering.

text.p: Singapore jet fuel prices soared on Monday on short covering by traders who had earlier sold into Japan, industry sources said.
Traders said the market was also boosted by talks of tight regional supplies as a result of the recent purchases by Japan, South Korea and China.

As a result of the short covering, premiums to North Asia rose with one 30,000-tonne cargo traded on Friday at a premium of close to $2.00 a barrel over spot Singapore quotes on a cost-and-freight basis to Japan, up about 20 cents from the previous deal, traders said.
In the Singapore physical market, a trader was offering a 100,000-barrel jet fuel cargo at $33.40 a barrel fob, up about $1.00 from Friday's bid level.

The December jet fuel/gas oil spread (regrade) rose substantially and was last quoted at $2.60/$2.80 a barrel, up from Friday's $1.80 bid level, brokers said. December jet fuel swaps traded at $33.00 a barrel.

Gas oil also firmed despite bearish news of India's January purchase of a low 255,000-tonnes, due to strong demand from China which is paying up to $249.00 per tonne for barge lots on an ex-terminal Hong Kong basis.
Gasoline was dull as the market prepared for the Taiwan buy tender for Jan 1-15 for unleaded reformate which closes today.

Traders said offers were above $27.00 a barrel c-and-f Taiwan, much higher than the last two cargoes purchased for Dec 16-31 delivery at slightly above $25.50. Only talk was heard on paper - an offer at $25.80 for December.
Naphtha swaps were largely uncchanged with December talked at $23.50/$23.70, compared to $23.55/$23.70 on Friday.
Fuel oil rose on healthy buying interest with two 20,000-tonne cargoes traded at $124.50 and $125.00 a tonne fob Singapore. --Singapore Newsroom (+65-870-3093)
